title: How to find my vocation - Quora

response.answer_text: Find something you truly love to do. Then, find a way to make money at it. To be a bit more detailed: you are young. At 17, you have a great deal of changing and growing to do. When you are 40, you should be a wildly different person. Today, for someone to find one career path and never deviate is rare. So, first is to not put too much pressure on yourself to find the end all by 18. However, to find something that should last a long time, look at the things you both love to do today, and what did you love to do over the last few years? Your interests change, but you may find some patterns. If you liked film, and have moved into music, what did you like about them? The creativity? Prestige? Challenge? Videos? Accessibility? What is it about those things you like? Start from there. Find a few people in a field you might like. Not the top people, but people who work in the field and maybe have not made it to the top. Don't try George Lucas, find a director who is still working their way up. Reach out to them and find a few who will allow you to talk to them for 15–30 mins. When the time comes, be prepared. Have questions ready. Ask them what it is like. You will find most jobs are nothing like what you think they are. I started out as an actor. After a few years of making a living at it, I realized that the real job of acting wasn't so much fun. So, I changed. Oh, and if you asked for 30 mins, stop at 30. Be respectful and don't waste their time. (If you are meeting in person, buy them a coffee.) At your age, find internships or like that so you can see what it is like. Depending on what you want to do, find the right person and ask to work for them, for free. Bust your butt to impress them. That's how you get experience and connections. Don't be afraid to try things. Jump in and do it. You will regret what you didn't try, not what you did try. Go do! In short, my guess is that you are over-thinking this and really need to learn to get out there and do things. Take a risk. At your age, failure is OK. I expect you don't have a wife and 3 kids to feed. (If you do, do not take my advice. You need to be much more conservative and fulfill your obligations to them, not just go and experience things.) Hope that helps!

The best way to discover your vocation is to find the ‘work you value’. Your vocation is based on your ideals which are developed in combination with your passions and your talents. Your vocation is the intersecting point between what ‘the world needs’ and ‘the work that others are prepared to pay you to do’. This work is oft-times different from the ‘work others value’ which is best tagged as your profession. Your profession is based on your strengths and is developed in conjunction with your experiences and your talents. Your profession is the work that you’re ‘great at doing’ and for which ‘others are prepared to pay you to do’. Your vocation is still work you get paid for, unlike your mission which is purely altruistically driven and defined by your values and your own meaning to life. Your mission becomes self evident from your life’s experiences and your identified passions. You mission is the work that you ‘love to do’ and which the ‘world needs’, but don’t expect others to pay you. Happiest are the people whose profession is also their vocation. Florin, at 17 you should start to identify a career. If I remember back to when I was 17 I was truly confused about what I wanted to do. From what you say it would seem you are more art oriented than, what I would call, hard science based subjects. Art is a wonderful sphere to be in because, almost by definition, the requirements for one sector overflows into another. Parents can be good, bad or indifferent when you are 17 but they have seen you grow up. They will know your strengths. Talk to them for input. You do not have to do as they say but take down notes. Then talk to others, it could be cousins, friends, people who see you doing things in normal life. You may find, if you are open, that there is a vocation right in front of you. It could be acting, story telling, writing or even something totally outside what you think would be your vocation such as design. In the world today there are so many career options it is hard to know what they all mean. When all is said and done though you will need to earn enough money to leave home and support your lifestyle. So choose wisely my friend. Alan

Sit down and relax. Become aware. Now move forward. Start to become more aware and realize what you enjoy doing naturally. What is in your nature? Once you realize what you truly like doing then think of ways to turn that into profit. Think of ways to turn that into helping others. You then have "found" your vocation.  One last thing... Don't look for anything. Just be aware of what is already there.  Tyler

I disagree with the idealists in other answers: find a job or major that you don’t hate and that can make you pay your bills. Purposedly I didn’t say “a job you love”, because that comes with time. The point is to keep moving and don’t starve. Meanwhile, develop good work habits and ethic. It is valid to change professions until you find something in which you feel well and competent, and it pays reasonably well for your lifestyle. Good luck and kind regards.

Ask yourself this question, "what did I *love* to play when I was between the ages of 7 and 12 years old?"  Chances are it's some sort of role-playing, but what roles did you like to play? And what can you synthesize or draw from that role? E.g. if you like to pretend you're a soldier, maybe there's something about being in a structured environment that you like. Going further with that, maybe you'll like work that involves devising some sort of structure e.g. civil engineering, structural engineering or even construction.

Read a book. Do things. Be a volunteer. Build some skills. Read Who are you Really?, by Gary Null. This book has personality tests (creative, assertive, adaptive …) and career advice.

I don’t know what the best way is yet, but one way is to answer people’s questions, a good place to do that is Quora. Having external stimulus that makes you think is a good way to self-reflect. We are made better students by becoming teachers ourselves. Explore your interests, try various things!

How about you make some films - seriously with your interests you should be creating film and populating your you-tube channel. With inexpensive cameras and free software such as black magic, you should be able to stick something together. It won’t have Hollywood production values, but you ought to be able to direct the production of some decent footage very inexpensively. I would have trouble believing that you were serious in this overcrowded area if you did not have some kind of portfolio
you will want to do it and will know it when you find it.
